bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, January 26, 1942

div1.p: Hench thanks Ireland for helping him gain access to Archives records, and for Ireland's hospitality towards him in Washington.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, January 26, 1942
div1.p:
Whenever I see your name written with the word “retired” after it
I will doubt the significance of that word. You may be officially retired
but most assuredly your influence is most alive and active. I don't know
what you told the men in the Adjutant General's office but the next day
when I arrived at the Archives Building, all was roses and honey suckle!
They couldn't have been nicer to me. They did everything they possibly
could for me, gave me practically all the records except the muster rolls
which they said I might copy but not photostat, etc. etc. I cannot tell
you how greatly I appreciate this and can only say again that I will try
to express my gratitude by a proper and scientific appraisal of the yellow
fever story and the proper use of the material which is being made available
to me.

Mary and I were so delighted with all the many courtesies which you
and others showed us in Washington. You were kindness itself. We were highly
honored to have you call at the hotel on Sunday and regretted that we were
not present. We were so glad to have you with us at our little dinner and
hope that you enjoyed the pictures of Havana. It was indeed a disappointment
for me not to visit General Kean but I hope to correct that on my next visit
to Washington.
Please give my kindest regards to Mrs. Ireland.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. General Merritt W. Ireland
1870 Wyoming Avenue N. W.
Washington, D. C.
